fields.value: Replication Data for "Is Door-to-Door Canvassing Effective in Europe? Evidence from a Meta-study across Six European Countries"

authorAffiliation.value: KORA - Danish Institute for Local and Regional Government Research

dsDescriptionValue.value:
A vast amount of experimental evidence suggests that Get-Out-The-Vote encouragements delivered through door-to-door canvassing delivers large effects on turnout. Most of the existing studies have been conducted in an American context, and are inspiring the mobilization efforts by European campaigns. Whether the American findings transfer to Europe is an empirical question, which we address in this article. Specifically, we compile the existing European studies and present two new Danish studies. We show that the pooled point estimate of the effect is substantially smaller in Europe compared to the findings from the US, and find no effects in the two Danish experiments. We discuss why the effects seem to be different in Europe compared to the US and stress the need for further experiments in Europe as there is still considerable uncertainty regarding the European effects. One suggestion is that differences in turnout rates explains the differences in effect sizes. However, the empirical analysis finds no strong relationship between turnout and effects sizes in either Europe or the US.

Replication for figure 1 and 2 along with Danish from the two Danish Get-out-the-vote Door-to-Door campaigns

R-files and a readme.file

keywordValue.value: mobilization, turnout, Get-Out-The-Vote, door-to-door canvassing, meta-study

fields.value:
replication for "Is Door-to-Door Canvassing Effective in Europe? Evidence from a Meta-study across Six European Countries".

Please see readme file for info on replication files

files.description: am_data.csv is data on American studies used in the meta-analysis. The vast majority of this information is sourced from replication files for Green, McGrath, and Aronow (2013) [see Bhatti et al. (2016) for full citation].
files.label: am_studies.csv

dataFile.description: am_data.csv is data on American studies used in the meta-analysis. The vast majority of this information is sourced from replication files for Green, McGrath, and Aronow (2013) [see Bhatti et al. (2016) for full citation].

files.description: bhatti_data_create.r creates the results using restricted access data that cannot be made available for public access due to requirements set by Statistics Denmark. The file also aggregates the data as much as possible to provide data that can be shared for replication in the other files.
files.label: bhatti_data_create.R

dataFile.description: bhatti_data_create.r creates the results using restricted access data that cannot be made available for public access due to requirements set by Statistics Denmark. The file also aggregates the data as much as possible to provide data that can be shared for replication in the other files.

files.description: bhatti_data_recreate.r takes the aggregated data and disaggregates a data frame with four variables: If the voter voted, her probability of treatment assignment, if she was assigned to treatment, and if the treatment was delivered to her.
files.label: bhatti_data_recreate.R

dataFile.description: bhatti_data_recreate.r takes the aggregated data and disaggregates a data frame with four variables: If the voter voted, her probability of treatment assignment, if she was assigned to treatment, and if the treatment was delivered to her.

files.description: bhatti_rep_file_1.r Creates all results reported in table S.1 and S.2 (not results in the notes for the table) and Danish results reported in table 1. It sources “bhatti_data_create.r”. The standard errors are adjusted by the scaling ratio explained under “bhatti_data_create.r” to adjust for clusters of households.
files.label: bhatti_rep_file_1.R

dataFile.description: bhatti_rep_file_1.r Creates all results reported in table S.1 and S.2 (not results in the notes for the table) and Danish results reported in table 1. It sources “bhatti_data_create.r”. The standard errors are adjusted by the scaling ratio explained under “bhatti_data_create.r” to adjust for clusters of households.

files.description: bhatti_rep_file_2.r runs the meta-analysis and produces figures 1 and 2.
files.label: bhatti_rep_file_2.R

dataFile.description: bhatti_rep_file_2.r runs the meta-analysis and produces figures 1 and 2.

files.description: rep_tabs.rdata contains aggregated data for the Danish experiments created using “bhatti_data_create.r”.
files.label: rep_tabs.rdata

dataFile.description: rep_tabs.rdata contains aggregated data for the Danish experiments created using “bhatti_data_create.r”.
